body:
Master doesn't build without building other snapshots right now.  Please
switch to the druid-0.5.x branch and run from there.

Hi Daggerrz,

Thanks for your contribution here and in Druid-API! Before I can merge the pull request, we need you to agree to our CLA. In the repo there is an individual CLA and a corporate CLA. If you are working on your own behalf and agree to the CLA, responding here with a comment of "I agree to the terms of the Druid Individual CLA as it exists in the current master branch" is sufficient. If you are working on behalf of a company, can you have your company fill out the corporate CLA and submit it to us?

Thanks,

This pull request generally looks good as far as the integration with Druid is concerned.  Nothing really seems to jump out at me as fundamentally wrong (mostly just ByteBuffer API usage and code style nits).

In the IRC channel, it was mentioned that the cardinalities seem to blow up suddenly as the number of things increases.  I haven't spent much time with the stream libraries, but I do remember we had a number of issues around our HLL implementation and merging of the intermediate forms.  There were some less-than-obvious bugs that we ran into and things we learned as we messed with it.  I'd start by trying to duplicate the event stream and merging that you expect Druid to be doing in a unit test on the library itself and see if you can reproduce there (and either eliminate it from the issue or figure out that it is the issue and give them a unit test to fix).
High level comment because I have not yet had time to look at this, but I think this pull request should directly be committed into Druid 0.6 to save the time to port things over.
This can be used for discussion. Will create a pull request for 0.6 soon. Need to understand how guice works :)
Closing in favor of https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/284
In our test the error is ~1%. Performance also looks good.
Closing this pull request as newer request has been created for 0.6.x code. Most of the comments are incorporated in it.

So, I haven't finished this code review, but I have some high level feedback. Unless @cheddar feel differently, I believe the query cache should be a separate, non-default module that we should be able to include as part of our deploy process if we choose to.
another high level comment, there are no unit tests whatsoever
third high level comment, I may be blind, but I don't see any logic to handle what happens when segments are obsoleted, has this code been tested?

I am in process of adding unit tests and once we figure out how to deploy newer version of druid on contegix will run integration-tests too on them. Most of the testing has been done manually only. 

If segments get obsolete the key will differ. The same needs to be discussed at `// TODO: Register segment callback`. 

About query cache as non-default module, I am not able to understand that. Guice docs are not that helpful :(.

Thanks again!

Deployed as of this morning in production. Will close the ticket when I don't see the error within a couple days.

That NPE sounds like the driver program can't find the segment descriptors that should have been written by hadoop reducers into your workingPath. The workingPath needs to be on HDFS; is it? Do you see any messages like "Writing descriptor to path[%s]" on your reducers?

UnsupportedClassVersionError usually means the Java compiler and Java runtime are not the same version: 

```
stephen$ JAVA_HOME=/System/Library/Frameworks/JavaVM.framework/Versions/1.7 ./run_example_server.sh
```

worked for me, as far as not crashing.

Not sure on the ls errors.
This is getting really really bad now, it's like happening within minutes event though I got 4 brokers (instead of two when using druid-0.4)

This issue only refers to behavior when there is an overabundance of broken connections, like connections to compute nodes that simply don't work or tcp connections stuck half-open due to compute crashes. I don't think any of that should be really common (hopefully not common enough to be "really bad" unless servers are constantly crashing) and am wondering if you are really seeing this issue or if you are seeing something similar but different.

What sort of symptoms are you seeing?

I see brokers simply not answering anymore.

My current working theory is the relationship of druid.broker.http.numConnections and druid.server.http.numThreads. Might that be it?

This is also a day 1 druid issue. The default timeout that was introduced
can be turned off by setting druid.broker.http.readTimeout to null or a
large value.
On Jan 14, 2014 7:49 AM, "Gian Merlino" notifications@github.com wrote:

> This issue only refers to behavior when there is an overabundance of
> broken connections, like connections to compute nodes that simply don't
> work or tcp connections stuck half-open due to compute crashes. I don't
> think any of that should be really common (hopefully not common enough to
> be "really bad" unless servers are constantly crashing) and am wondering if
> you are really seeing this issue or if you are seeing something similar but
> different.
> 
> What sort of symptoms are you seeing?
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/metamx/druid/issues/325#issuecomment-32276060
> .

The query path goes like broker http thread -> broker compute connection pool -> compute http threads -> compute computation pools. Can you tell which resource is the one blocking things? Thread dumps and netstats during an outage are good ways of figuring that out.

If one of the broker resources is blocking things, then those properties you mentioned are a good place to start looking for a solution. If the compute resources look more problematic, there are also properties for number of compute http threads (druid.server.http.numThreads) and the size of the computation pool (druid.processing.numThreads).

There is an undocumented config requirement:

[num of brokers] \* broker:druid.processing.numThreads > historical:druid.server.http.numThreads

Otherwise you get unresponsive brokers very quickly under query load.

If you step back a sec, that seems very obvious. It's just not documented explicitly and I ran into it.

Do you mean greater than the total number of http threads across all
historical nodes, or greater than then number of http threads on each
historical node?

This requirement may also be very specific to your work-load. I believe it
would greatly depend on your cache hit-rate and how many queries actually
get sent down to historical nodes vs. how many results get pulled from
cache.

Fixed by #361

Actually this is affecting all examples because it's the same script to start the node, but the correct JAR is loaded after all. All that is needed is script cleanup so that the script no longer searches for the self-contained JAR when it starts.

This is an artifact of the API which currently refers to anything that is not an aggregate as a dimension, which doesn't translate very well in that case. We would have to change the api to correct for this misnomer.
Has this issue resurfaced?

I'm trying to build from source and this test keeps failing.  Was there any solution?

Hi Adam, we haven't done anything to address the problem yet.
The initial ticket has a better description of the problem:
https://github.com/metamx/druid/issues/275

If this test is failing when you are building from source, you can also
just simply comment out the @Test annotation as a workaround.
